description.narrative: The study revealed that the impact of the ECtHR on the freedom of expression was limited.ECtHR has rendered many judgments against Turkey with regard to Articles 10 and 11. Such judgments were sent to the Council of Ministers for the enforcement thereof and many legislative amendments were made during the process of enforcement. However, these amendments have rendered the legislation more unpredictable let alone sorting out the problem as the proceedings before the ECtHR are conducted in a case-based fashion. The second assessment was that the main problem of Turkish Criminal Law relating to terror-related crimes is vagueness and unforseeability. Thus, this constitutes a structural and systemic problem in the Turkish law. The projects report demonstrates that a systematic violation of the freedom of expression and association is present with the arbitrary implementation of the provisions in various criminal legislation. The aforementioned state of uncertainty is not related to the consideration of the context for analyzing the meaning of the statement, but to the transformation of a non-incriminating action into an offense with a change in the political atmosphere. Penalizing a statement not through its meaning valid at the time of expression, but through its emerging meaning years later. The study stressess the importance of the freedom of expression as a constitutional principle and, more importantly, the principle of legal predictability apart from an analysis of criminal law. Recommendations were made to the Government of the Republic of Turkey, national judicial bodies, ECtHR and the Council of Europe.
